title: Inspection Reports for Purpose Built Student Accomodation in Walkley and City Wards

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide the following information under the Freedom Of Information Act: -
Written answers from the Sheffield Council Housing policy committee meeting 14th September state that
"We have 27 Purpose Built Student Accommodation block registered with
Snug in Walkley and City Wards, all of which have been inspected within
the last 2 years.",  (answer to Q3 of these questions
https://democracy.sheffield.gov.uk/docum...
)
Please provide the inspection reports for each of the 27 properties alluded to.
Yours faithfully,
Matt Smith

Dear Matt Smith
We regret the delay in responding to your request of 1 October 2023 which
was due on 30 October 2023. We had all the information on 2 November 2023
but omitted to send it to you. We sincerely apologise for your frustration
and you having to complain to the Information Commissioner’s Office.
The Snug scheme is a partnership by the council and universities for
monitoring and regulation of student housing in Sheffield. We do not
compile inspection reports as part of the Snug scheme. We note hazards and
issues that do not meet the standards and raise them with the
landlord/managing agent.
The Snug property and management standards also provide an inspection
standard:
[1]snug_property_and_management_standards_from_1_august_2023_0.pdf
(sheffield.gov.uk)
We are attaching a copy of a letter where work is required. Following each
inspection, a letter is sent either passing the property as no work is
required or requesting work to be undertaken. Once the work has been
completed and checked off another letter is sent passing the property. We
have removed personal data under Section 40(2) of the Act because it would
otherwise be a breach of the data protection principles.
Potentially 54 letters (i.e., two letters each for 27 blocks of
accommodation) could have gone out. It is impossible to know exact numbers
that required work without entering each account on our database, and then
reviewing each file. We estimate this would take 27 hours which would
exceed the cost of compliance of 18 hours. That is because we would have
to review ethe records for each block and retrieve and extract the
information. If you want to pursue this interest, please consider a
narrower focus for your request for information.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [2]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[3]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
